trig-node-1.title: Identifying Triangle Parts Relative to an Angle
learningFocus: Identify hypotenuse (opposite the right angle)
Identify opposite side (opposite to the given angle)
Identify adjacent side (next to the given angle, not hypotenuse)

exemplarProblems.problemText: In triangle ABC with right angle at C and considering angle A, identify: (i) the hypotenuse, (ii) the opposite side, (iii) the adjacent side.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: (i) AB (hypotenuse), (ii) BC (opposite to angle A), (iii) AC (adjacent to angle A)

exemplarProblems.problemText: Triangle PQR has a right angle at R. With reference to angle P, which side is the opposite side?
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: QR (the side opposite to angle P)

questionFormats: With reference to angle {A}, which side is the opposite side?
Identify the adjacent side to angle {A}
List all three sides: hypotenuse, opposite to angle {A}, adjacent to angle {A}

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question per problem asking to identify sides relative to a given angle
CRITICAL: Include mathTool showing labeled triangle to help understanding
DO NOT show numeric side lengths initially - use letters (AB, BC, etc.)
Vary triangle orientation (rotate which vertex has right angle)
Emphasize that opposite and adjacent are RELATIVE to the angle being considered
In caption, specify: 'Identify sides with reference to angle {A}'
Set angle parameter to 0 and angleLabel to the reference angle letter
Students must understand: hypotenuse is always the same, but opposite and adjacent change depending on which angle is referenced

trig-node-2.title: Stating the Three Trigonometric Ratios
learningFocus: State sin θ = Opposite / Hypotenuse
State cos θ = Adjacent / Hypotenuse
State tan θ = Opposite / Adjacent
Recall SOH-CAH-TOA mnemonic

exemplarProblems.problemText: In a right-angled triangle, write down an expression for sin θ in terms of opposite (opp), adjacent (adj), and hypotenuse (hyp).
Complete the ratio: cos θ = ?/?
What does the 'TOA' in SOH-CAH-TOA represent?

questionTypes: What does {ratio} equal in terms of opposite, adjacent, hypotenuse?

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question per problem - ask to state ONE ratio
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool - this is about stating formulas from memory
Questions should test knowledge of SOH-CAH-TOA
Accept multiple formats: 'O/H', 'opp/hyp', 'Opposite/Hypotenuse'
Ensure students understand what each letter in SOH-CAH-TOA represents
Do not ask for numeric calculations yet - just ratio definitions

trig-node-3.title: Calculating Exact Ratio Values from Diagrams
learningFocus: Calculate sin θ, cos θ, or tan θ given labeled triangle
Express ratios as fractions
Understand ratios are side lengths divided

exemplarProblems.problemText: In triangle ABC, angle A = 30°, BC = 5 cm (opposite), AC = 10 cm (hypotenuse). Calculate sin 30° as a fraction.
A right-angled triangle has opposite = 3, adjacent = 4, hypotenuse = 5. Find tan θ.

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question asking to calculate ONE ratio
CRITICAL: Include mathTool showing triangle with numeric side lengths
Use Pythagorean triples for clean fraction answers
Question gives side lengths and asks for ratio value (not solving for side)
Students should: 1) Identify which sides are opp, adj, hyp, 2) Apply formula, 3) Calculate fraction
Accept answers as fractions or decimals
Set angleLabel to \\theta to show the angle symbol

trig-node-4.title: Finding Opposite Side Using Sine
learningFocus: Apply: sin θ = opposite / hypotenuse
Rearrange to: opposite = hypotenuse × sin θ
Use calculator in degree mode

exemplarProblems.problemText: In a right-angled triangle, angle A = 35°, hypotenuse = 10 cm. Find the length of the opposite side to 1 decimal place.
Triangle ABC has a right angle at C. Angle B = 48°, AB = 20 m. Find the length of AC to 2 decimal places.

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question - find the opposite side only
CRITICAL: Include mathTool showing angle and hypotenuse
DO NOT show opposite side value in mathTool - that's what student must find
Set mathTool angle parameter to the numeric angle value
Question provides: angle and hypotenuse
Student must: 1) Identify using sine, 2) Rearrange to opposite = hyp × sin θ, 3) Calculate
Always specify rounding precision
Use realistic angle values (20° to 70°)
Include units and require units in answer

trig-node-5.title: Finding Hypotenuse Using Sine
learningFocus: Rearrange to: hypotenuse = opposite / sin θ
Distinguish from finding opposite (divide vs multiply)

exemplarProblems.problemText: A right-angled triangle has angle 37°, opposite side 5 cm. Find the hypotenuse to 1 decimal place.
In triangle PQR with right angle at R, angle P = 52°, QR = 12 m. Find the length of PQ to 2 decimal places.

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question - find hypotenuse using sine
CRITICAL: Include mathTool showing angle and opposite side
DO NOT show hypotenuse in mathTool
Question provides: angle and opposite side
Emphasize rearrangement: hypotenuse = opposite / sin θ (DIVIDE, not multiply)
Common error: students may multiply instead of divide - question should prompt correct thinking
Specify rounding precision
Verify answer makes sense: hypotenuse > opposite

trig-node-6.title: Finding Adjacent Side Using Cosine
learningFocus: Apply: cos θ = adjacent / hypotenuse
Rearrange to: adjacent = hypotenuse × cos θ
Distinguish adjacent from opposite

exemplarProblems.problemText: In a right-angled triangle, angle = 40°, hypotenuse = 15 cm. Find the length of the adjacent side to 1 decimal place.
Triangle XYZ has a right angle at Z. Angle X = 55°, XZ = 12 m. Find the length of XY (the hypotenuse) - Wait, this is finding hypotenuse. CORRECTION: Angle X = 55°, XY = 18 m. Find XZ to 2 dp.

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question - find adjacent side using cosine
CRITICAL: Include mathTool showing angle and hypotenuse
DO NOT show adjacent side in mathTool
Question provides: angle and hypotenuse
Student must: 1) Recognize to use cosine (adjacent and hypotenuse), 2) Rearrange, 3) Calculate
Emphasize difference from sine: cosine uses ADJACENT not opposite
Set mathTool to show opposite side (to make clear which is adjacent)
Specify rounding precision

trig-node-7.title: Finding Hypotenuse Using Cosine
learningFocus: Rearrange to: hypotenuse = adjacent / cos θ

exemplarProblems.problemText: A right-angled triangle has angle 58°, adjacent side 12 m. Find the hypotenuse to 1 decimal place.

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question - find hypotenuse using cosine
CRITICAL: Include mathTool showing angle and adjacent side
DO NOT show hypotenuse
Question provides: angle and adjacent
Rearrangement: hypotenuse = adjacent / cos θ (DIVIDE)
Specify rounding

trig-node-8.title: Finding Opposite Side Using Tangent
learningFocus: Apply: tan θ = opposite / adjacent
Rearrange to: opposite = adjacent × tan θ
Recognize tangent does NOT use hypotenuse

exemplarProblems.problemText: In a right-angled triangle, angle = 42°, adjacent side = 15 cm. Find the opposite side to 1 decimal place.
Triangle PQR has a right angle at R. Angle P = 48°, PR = 20 m. Find QR to 2 decimal places.

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question - find opposite using tangent
CRITICAL: Include mathTool showing angle and adjacent side
DO NOT show opposite or hypotenuse in mathTool
Question provides: angle and adjacent
Emphasize: Use tangent when hypotenuse is NOT involved
Student must: 1) Recognize tan (no hypotenuse), 2) Rearrange to opp = adj × tan θ, 3) Calculate
Specify rounding

trig-node-9.title: Finding Adjacent Side Using Tangent
learningFocus: Rearrange to: adjacent = opposite / tan θ

exemplarProblems.problemText: A right-angled triangle has angle 35°, opposite side 12 cm. Find the adjacent side to 1 decimal place.

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question - find adjacent using tangent
CRITICAL: Include mathTool showing angle and opposite
DO NOT show adjacent or hypotenuse
Rearrangement: adjacent = opposite / tan θ (DIVIDE)
Specify rounding

trig-node-10.title: Choosing the Correct Ratio
learningFocus: Determine which ratio to use based on given and unknown sides
Decision tree: which sides are involved?

exemplarProblems.problemText: A right-angled triangle has angle 45°. You are given the opposite side and need to find the adjacent side. Which trigonometric ratio should you use?
In a right triangle, you know the angle is 50° and the hypotenuse is 20 cm. You need to find the opposite side. State which ratio to use and set up the equation.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: Use sine. sin 50° = opposite / 20, so opposite = 20 × sin 50°

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question asking to identify the correct ratio
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool - this is about decision-making, not calculation
Question describes what is given and what needs to be found
Student must: 1) Identify which sides are involved, 2) Choose correct ratio
Accept: naming the ratio (sine/cosine/tangent) AND/OR setting up equation
This tests understanding of WHEN to use each ratio, not calculation skills
Mix different combinations of given/unknown

trig-node-11.title: Finding Angles Using Inverse Sine
learningFocus: Use sin⁻¹ when opposite and hypotenuse are given
Calculate ratio first, then apply inverse function
Understand inverse functions 'undo' trig functions

exemplarProblems.problemText: A right-angled triangle has opposite side 6 cm and hypotenuse 10 cm. Find the angle to the nearest degree.
In triangle ABC with right angle at C, BC = 8 m, AB = 15 m. Find angle A to 1 decimal place.

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question - find ONE angle using sin⁻¹
CRITICAL: Include mathTool showing opposite and hypotenuse with numeric values
DO NOT show angle value - set angle to 0 and angleLabel to \\theta
Question provides: opposite and hypotenuse side lengths
Student must: 1) Calculate ratio (opp/hyp), 2) Use sin⁻¹ on calculator, 3) Round appropriately
Emphasize process: ratio first, THEN inverse function
Specify rounding precision
Verify answer is between 0° and 90° for right triangle

trig-node-12.title: Finding Angles Using Inverse Cosine
learningFocus: Use cos⁻¹ when adjacent and hypotenuse are given

exemplarProblems.problemText: A right-angled triangle has adjacent side 8 m and hypotenuse 15 m. Find the angle to 1 decimal place.

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question - find angle using cos⁻¹
CRITICAL: Include mathTool showing adjacent and hypotenuse
Question provides: adjacent and hypotenuse
Process: Calculate ratio (adj/hyp), then θ = cos⁻¹(ratio)
Specify rounding

trig-node-13.title: Finding Angles Using Inverse Tangent
learningFocus: Use tan⁻¹ when opposite and adjacent are given

exemplarProblems.problemText: A right-angled triangle has opposite side 12 cm and adjacent side 9 cm. Find the angle to the nearest degree.

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question - find angle using tan⁻¹
CRITICAL: Include mathTool showing opposite and adjacent
Question provides: opposite and adjacent (no hypotenuse)
Process: Calculate ratio (opp/adj), then θ = tan⁻¹(ratio)
Emphasize: Use tan⁻¹ when hypotenuse is NOT involved
Specify rounding

trig-node-14.title: Angle of Elevation - Finding Height
learningFocus: Define angle of elevation (measured UP from horizontal)
Set up right triangle from elevation context
Use tan to find height (typically)

exemplarProblems.problemText: A person stands 50 m from the base of a building. The angle of elevation to the top is 35°. Find the height of the building to 1 decimal place.
From a point on level ground 38 m from the foot of a building, the angle of elevation to the top is 33°. Calculate the height of the building to 3 significant figures.

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question - find height using angle of elevation
CRITICAL: Include mathTool with type='elevation' showing the setup
DO NOT include height parameter in mathTool - that's what student must find
Question provides: horizontal distance and angle of elevation
Student must: 1) Recognize right triangle (horizontal, vertical, line of sight), 2) Use tan (height/distance), 3) Rearrange and calculate
Common formula: tan(angle) = height / distance, so height = distance × tan(angle)
Use realistic contexts: person looking up at building, tree, tower
Specify rounding precision
Include units in answer

trig-node-15.title: Angle of Elevation - Finding Distance
learningFocus: Use angle of elevation to find horizontal distance
Rearrange: distance = height / tan(angle)

exemplarProblems.problemText: A tower is 40 m tall. From a point on level ground, the angle of elevation to the top is 37°. Find the distance from the point to the base of the tower to 1 decimal place.

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question - find distance using elevation
CRITICAL: Include mathTool showing angle and height
DO NOT include distance parameter
Question provides: height and angle of elevation
Rearrangement: distance = height / tan(angle)
Specify rounding

trig-node-16.title: Angle of Depression - Understanding
learningFocus: Define angle of depression (measured DOWN from horizontal)
Recognize alternate angles (depression from A to B = elevation from B to A)
Set up triangle correctly

exemplarProblems.problemText: From the top of an 80 m cliff, the angle of depression to a boat is 28°. Find the horizontal distance from the base of the cliff to the boat to 1 decimal place.
An observer on a 45 m lighthouse sees a ship at an angle of depression of 15°. Calculate the distance from the lighthouse base to the ship to the nearest metre.

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question - find distance using angle of depression
CRITICAL: Include mathTool with type='depression'
DO NOT include distance parameter in mathTool
Question provides: height of observer and angle of depression
Student must: 1) Understand depression angle, 2) Recognize right triangle, 3) Use tan(angle) = height/distance
Emphasize: Angle of depression from observer = angle of elevation from target (alternate angles)
Use contexts: cliff/boat, lighthouse/ship, tower/car, building/person
Set observerLabel and targetLabel appropriately
Specify rounding

trig-node-17.title: Ladder Problems - Real-World Applications
learningFocus: Identify right triangle in ladder context
Determine what is given and unknown
Choose appropriate ratio

exemplarProblems.problemText: A 12 m ladder leans against a wall, making an angle of 68° with the ground. How high up the wall does the ladder reach? Give your answer to 1 decimal place.
A ladder is placed 3 m from the base of a wall and reaches 8 m up the wall. Find the angle the ladder makes with the ground to the nearest degree.

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question per problem
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool - let student visualize ladder triangle
Use realistic ladder scenarios
Vary what is given and what needs to be found
Question should describe practical situation clearly
Student must: 1) Draw/visualize triangle, 2) Identify given values, 3) Choose ratio, 4) Calculate
Specify rounding precision
Include units in answer

trig-node-18.title: Kite and Flagpole Problems
learningFocus: Apply trigonometry to string/height problems
Identify when to use sine vs tangent

exemplarProblems.problemText: A kite string is 85 m long. The angle of elevation from the person holding the string to the kite is 42°. Find the height of the kite above the ground to 1 decimal place.
A flagpole casts a shadow 24 m long when the sun's angle of elevation is 58°. Find the height of the flagpole to 1 decimal place.

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question per problem
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool
Kite problems: Use sine (string is hypotenuse, find opposite/height)
Shadow problems: Use tangent (shadow is adjacent, find opposite/height)
Question describes realistic scenario
Student must determine which ratio based on what represents what in triangle
Specify rounding

trig-node-19.title: Ramp and Slope Problems
learningFocus: Find angle of incline given rise and run
Apply trigonometry to slope contexts

exemplarProblems.problemText: A ramp rises 2.5 m over a horizontal distance of 18 m. Find the angle of incline to the nearest degree.
A wheelchair ramp must have a maximum angle of 5°. If it rises 0.8 m, what is the minimum horizontal length required? Give your answer to 1 decimal place.

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question per problem
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool
Use realistic ramp/slope scenarios
Typically use tangent: tan(angle) = rise / run
Can ask for angle given rise and run, OR ask for distance given rise and angle
Include accessibility context (wheelchair ramps)
Specify rounding

trig-node-20.title: Mixed Real-World Applications
learningFocus: Choose appropriate trigonometric approach independently
Solve varied contextual problems
Interpret results with units

exemplarProblems.problemText: A tree casts a 24 m shadow when the sun's angle of elevation is 58°. Find the height of the tree to 1 decimal place.
From an observer on a 45 m high building, a car on the road has an angle of depression of 32°. How far is the car from the base of the building to the nearest metre?

contexts: Tree and shadow (find height using tangent)
Building and car with depression angle (find distance)
Plane altitude and angle to airport (find horizontal distance)
Mountain climber on cliff looking down at camp (find distance)

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question per problem
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool - student must set up problem independently
Use diverse, realistic contexts
Mix finding sides (using sin/cos/tan) and finding angles (using inverses)
Student must: 1) Draw diagram, 2) Label knowns and unknowns, 3) Choose ratio, 4) Solve, 5) Interpret with units
Questions should require minimal scaffolding - students work independently
Specify rounding and always require units
Contexts should be engaging and practical
